topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Cold open on job search focus ("spear not a net"), then Lenny introduces Phyl Terry, his background, and the episode’s goal: practical job-search tactics for finding a job you love.

topics.title: What Job Search Councils are
topics.summary: Phyl explains Job Search Councils as small peer support groups (6–8) that follow a structured methodology to reduce anxiety, build accountability, and help people "play to win" in interviews and negotiation.

topics.title: Origins: Phyl’s mom and tough markets
topics.summary: Phyl traces the council concept to his mother’s teacher council (met for 50 years) and explains how the method was forged in difficult job markets (1970s, dot-com bust).

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Ads for Sidebar (peer groups for senior tech leaders) and Sprig (product experience insights with AI).

topics.title: Scale, funding, and how councils operate
topics.summary: Phyl shares the scale (2,000+ councils), volunteer-driven model, and how book sales fund operations; then details matching, fast vs slow seeker tracks, moderator role, onboarding, and meeting cadence.

topics.title: Impact stories and emotional balance sheet
topics.summary: Phyl reads testimonials and emphasizes that the most important thing to manage in a job search is emotional balance; councils provide motivation, accountability, and resilience through vulnerability and support.

topics.title: Why you shouldn’t search alone
topics.summary: Phyl pitches the value of councils to skeptics via an introvert success story and broader context on loneliness; Lenny and Phyl frame councils as real community with practical tools.

topics.title: Building a private safety net and mission
topics.summary: Phyl explains the mission as a private safety net for layoffs, tying it to capitalism’s creative destruction: innovation creates anxiety and dislocation, and community-based job-search support addresses that gap.

topics.title: Candidate market fit: concept and first steps
topics.summary: Phyl introduces candidate market fit as a supply/demand reality (not personal worth), urges people to stop "spray and pray," and start with the Mnookin two-pager (wants/don’ts) to clarify direction.

topics.title: Listening tour: market research and relationships
topics.summary: Phyl outlines the listening tour (reverse exit interviews, broader network with the "golden question," and recruiters) to validate fit, gather market signals, and turn contacts into invested "listening posts."

topics.title: Narrowing your CMF: spear not a net
topics.summary: Phyl explains how to craft a tight 1-sentence CMF (3–4 attributes) and why narrow beats broad: people can expand from a specific target but can’t reduce from "I’ll take anything."

topics.title: Choosing attributes and stage; startups vs big tech
topics.summary: They discuss what goes into the CMF grid (role/level, industry, stage, culture constraints like remote) and how current market dynamics may favor startups, while acknowledging tradeoffs and "two-step" paths.

topics.title: Hard truths: downleveling, two-step strategies, frontier
topics.summary: Phyl shares examples where senior leaders needed to go IC to enter top companies, explains two-step strategies, and warns about getting stuck away from the technology frontier; emphasizes realism plus support.

topics.title: Staying active: updates, accountability, and the 'I in village'
topics.summary: Phyl advises monthly network update notes, warns against going passive (leaving councils, stopping networking), and reframes community support as increasing personal agency and accountability in a tough market.
